title: Facebook Wanted Out of Politics. It Was Messier Than Anyone Expected.

last_post.content:
There are two pieces of news in this one:

https://www.wsj.com/articles/facebook-politics-controls-zuckerberg-meta-11672929976?mod=tech_lead_pos2
 
1.     In late 2021, with zero fanfare, Facebook began changing newsfeed worldwide to exclude comments and reshares in how it promotes politics, societal and health-related content.

2.     This wasn’t enough for FB’s leadership and board. Late in 2021, they asked Facebook to move forward with zero-weighting ALL civic content in newsfeed. Facebook wanted out of politics.

Die Buddha-Statuen von Bamiyan wurden im 6. Jh. n. Chr. von buddhistischen Mönchen aus dem Fels gehauen.
Im März 2001 begannen die Taliban die Statuen restlos zu zerstören. Damit wollten sie ein Zeichen gegen Kultur & Toleranz setzen.

The number of active Mastodon users — those who've logged in in the last 30 days — has fallen to 1.8 million from a high of 2.6 million. This reflects the fact that while there's a wave of new users after each Musk tantrum, the majority aren't sticking around. Even the 1.8M figure is inflated by new accounts, so I expect a further drop.

Still, the number of active users is over 4 times what it used to be before the Twitter takeover.

Source: https://api.joinmastodon.org/statistics (and Wayback machine).

title: How Twitter misleads us about how many people have left — and what to do about it

last_post.content:
Who do so many people seem unaware of the mass exodus from Twitter?

Social media feeds are engines for distorting our social understanding. But we can push back against the algorithm, with a simple automated out-of-office message on Twitter (how-to included).

This post explains the science of social influence that allows Twitter to maintain an illusion of a full room, how to change that, & why we need industry-independent science for our digital environments.

https://natematias.medium.com/how-twitter-misleads-us-about-how-many-people-have-left-and-what-to-do-about-it-bba484b6fed6

If you don't know what this is about start reading a summary by @johncarlosbaez here: https://johncarlosbaez.wordpress.com/2022/12/22/dividing-a-square-into-similar-rectangles/

In this thread I will prove here that the allowed ratios in a similar-rectangulation with \(N\) rectangles are always zeros of a polynomial of degree at most \(N\).

For every (generic) rectangulation there is a pair of directed graphs recording the relative positions of the rectangles, a horizontal graph and a vertical graph.
1/n

title: Papers and patents are becoming less disruptive over time - Nature

last_post.content:
Taking a closer look at this paper, I really dislike it.

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-022-05543-x

It's clear that newer papers *must* have a lower “disruption” score than older ones under a null model — they even confirm this in the supplemental material with a randomization test. It's an artifact of their definition.

When comparing with the null model they compute only the z-score, getting values at most 4 or so. It's also besides the point — as usual, small meaningless deviations from the null model can be statistically “significant.” Effect size ≠ statistical significance.

Finally, according to their definition, review papers would be “disruptive” because they funnel a bunch of citations. And a paper that does not cite anyone but is universally cited would not be “disruptive”. 🤷

@networkscience
@academicchatter
#networkscience #networks

title: Pop Culture Pulsar: Origin Story of Joy Division’s Unknown Pleasures Album Cover [Video]

last_post.content:
Evening addendum: The image on the cover of the Joy Division album "Unknown Pleasures" is from a plot that radio astronomer Harold Craft made for his PhD dissertation, using data collected at Arecibo while studying the pulsar discovered by Jocelyn Bell Burnell.

This Scientific American article tracks down the original sources and links to video of an interview with album cover designer Peter Saville:
https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/sa-visual/pop-culture-pulsar-origin-story-of-joy-division-s-unknown-pleasures-album-cover-video/

title: GitHub - idoerg/papertooter: A script to post manuscripts from biorxiv to Mastodon using a unique hashtag based on the manuscript DOI.

last_post.content:
Announcing papertooter. Papertooter is a simple script that takes the URL of a biorxiv preprint, and posts the title and link to the paper on Mastodon using the Mastodon Python API. It also posts a unique hashtag it generates from the paper's DOI. Good for paper posting bots, or just for your own paper posting fun.

Feature requests and bug reports welcome.

https://github.com/idoerg/papertooter

title: Gaussian-state Ansatz for the non-equilibrium dynamics of quantum spin lattices

last_post.content:
Today's #arXivsummary: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.01363 by Menu & Roscilde. Authors propose Gaussian Ansatz for the study of the nonequilibrium dynamics of quantum spin systems. The Gaussian Ansatz, when applied to the bosonic Hamiltonian with nonlinearities truncated to quartic order, is able to reproduce faithfully
the evolution of the state. A such, a Gaussian Ansatz correctly captures the essential effects of nonlinearities in quantum spin dynamics. #CondMat #StrEl #arXiv_2301_01363

title: GitHub is Sued, and We May Learn Something About Creative Commons Licensing

last_post.content:
"I have long wondered about the interplay between the attribution requirement (in CC BY) and TDM...Does [it] need to include attribution, even if hundreds of thousands of CC BY works were mined?"
https://scholarlykitchen.sspnet.org/2023/01/05/github-is-sued-and-we-may-learn-something-about-creative-commons-licensing/

I too have wondered about this given only vague assurances from CC BY advocates rather than anything concrete in the license itself.

BUT a much better argument is that TDM is allowed under copyright, which means this is allowable whatever the license https://lawreview.law.ucdavis.edu/issues/53/2/articles/files/53-2_Carroll.pdf

"I have long wondered about the interplay between the attribution requirement (in CC BY) and TDM...Does [it] need to include attribution, even if hundreds of thousands of CC BY works were mined?"
https://scholarlykitchen.sspnet.org/2023/01/05/github-is-sued-and-we-may-learn-something-about-creative-commons-licensing/

BUT a much better argument is that TDM is allowed under copyright, which means this is allowable whatever the license https://lawreview.law.ucdavis.edu/issues/53/2/articles/files/53-2_Carroll.pdf

title: NICAR23 Pre-Registered Classes - Investigative Reporters & Editors

last_post.content:
Both classes have been taught before, are fully scripted out and, crucially, require preregistration.

Seats are limited. Past years have sold out. If you are interested, you should register today.

I have been to more than a dozen NICARs and, IMHO, these in-depth sessions are the best part of the conference. It's where I see students really learn.

Not interested in my offer? Check the full menu. It's certain there's one for you.

title: Snow crystals, observed by James Glaisher, Esq., F.R.S., from February 8th to March 10th, 1855.

last_post.content: Oh man, look at these special snowflakes--no, really, they're quite lovely. Mid-19th century plates depicting snowflakes under the microscope created by James and Cecilia Glaisher. https://onlineonly.christies.com/s/printed-manuscript-americana-science/snow-crystals-observed-james-glaisher-esq-f-r-s-february-8th-march-35/173677?ldp_breadcrumb=back

https://ire.org/training/conferences/nicar-2023/

It's the best opportunity anywhere for journalists to learn practical data skills.

This year I'll help teach two lengthy bootcamps, where students get hands on.

Here's the story. 🧵

"Untergunther, réparateurs clandestins du patrimoine."

C'était il y a 12 ans : un groupe clandestin, Untergunther, achevait les réparations, secrètes, de l'horloge du Panthéon de Paris, menées pendant un an. Depuis, discrètement, en usant des souterrains parisiens pour se déplacer, ils continuent de restaurer le patrimoine de la capitale.

#culture #art #Paris #Untergunther

https://www.radiofrance.fr/franceculture/untergunther-reparateurs-clandestins-du-patrimoine-9202861

title: How About We Put Learning at the Center? | Inside Higher Ed

last_post.content:
"Sometimes, the artifact the student produces that reflects a genuine learning moment is judged poorly according to the criteria valued in academic spaces, because learning is messy. Because of this, it is safer for students to write in ways that express the already known, to produce what I call writing-related simulations.

Enter ChatGPT, an algorithm that cannot think but is great at producing simulations of thinking."

https://www.insidehighered.com/blogs/just-visiting/how-about-we-put-learning-center

title: Electric Vehicles Are Bringing Out the Worst in Us

last_post.content:
"At the risk of stating the obvious, such blistering acceleration serves no practical purpose on a public road, where it can jeopardize everyone’s safety."

A good piece on the quixotic problem of electric-vehicle adoption in the US: The auto industry is seeing its hugest profits from electrifying the sprawlingly huge SUV and truck market -- but those vehicles, once electric, are both much heavier and much faster, making them ever-more dangerous to those around them

https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2023/01/electric-vehicles-suv-battery-climate-safety/672576/

title: How much do APCs cost French research institutions?

last_post.content:
#France paid €31 million for article processing charges (#APCs) in 2020, about 3x what it paid in 2013. It predicts it will pay between €50m and €68m for APCs in 2030.

In addition, it paid €87.5m for #subscriptions in 2020 and predicts it could pay €97.5m in 2030.
https://www.ouvrirlascience.fr/how-much-do-apcs-cost-french-research-institutions/

last_post.content:
We will be opening up around 2000 more TestFlight spots in about 1 hour (9:00am CST) from the timestamp of this post!

2. Check this TestFlight link at around 9 for the spots to open back up: https://testflight.apple.com/join/iDgGfyeO (It's going to say it is full right now).

title: McCarthy makes fresh concessions to try to woo hard-right Republicans in speaker bid

last_post.content:
In a stunning reversal, Kevin McCarthy offered to lower from five lawmakers to one the threshold required to sponsor a resolution to force a vote to oust the speaker — a change the California Republican had previously said he would not accept

https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2023/01/05/mccarthy-republicans-concessions-speaker/

title: Bluebottle hackers used signed Windows driver in attacks on banks

last_post.content:
A signed Windows driver has been used in attacks on banks in French-speaking countries, likely from a threat actor that stole more than $11 million from various banks.

https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/bluebottle-hackers-used-signed-windows-driver-in-attacks-on-banks/

While ChatGPT is all the rage these days, as you may know it doesn't optimize for accuracy, but rather something like plausability.

I would thus like to highlight an alternative that only answers based on scientific papers, and does so while referencing all the sources:

https://elicit.org

To me, this is pretty awesome! Let's encourage this type of projects that promote accuracy and transparency of its sources!
